name: Superposition and Interference in Swarms
description: The ability of a swarm to exhibit quantum-like properties, specifically interference patterns, by maintaining a probabilistic wavefunction state rather than a definite position.
findings: Implemented a Quantum Swarm where agents are represented by a collective wavefunction.
The swarm exhibited 4 distinct interference peaks on the screen, whereas a classical control showed only 1 merged peak.
This confirms that the swarm can operate in superposition and process information via wave interference.
implications: Swarms can perform quantum-like search algorithms (Grover-like).
Probabilistic logic allows for exploring multiple paths simultaneously.
Interference can be used for pattern matching and decision making.
